context: Other variables such as age, outdoor activities, and exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (smoking at home of the father and mother and number of cigarettes smoked) were not significant confounders and were not included in the final models. In models including traffic count, we also account for the distance between the home and the traffic count device located on the main avenue closest to the home. We also evaluated the potential modifying effect of asthma severity on the relationship between pollutant exposure and malondialdehyde levels. Association of malondialdehyde levels with health outcomes Generalized estimating equation models were used to study the association between malondialdehyde levels and pulmonary function (forced vital capacity [FVC] and FEV1) and IL-8 levels in nasal lavage. We also calculated the predicted FEV1 and FVC using the equation proposed by Peréz-Padilla et al 14 for Mexican children and calculated the association between malondialdehyde levels and changes in FEV1% and FVC%. IL-8 levels were not normally distributed and were log-transformed. Models were adjusted for sex, body mass index, and chronological time when studying lung function and for sex and chronological time only in models including IL-8 given that body mass index was not significantly related to IL-8 levels.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, malondialdehyde (MDA) levels are evaluated for their association with pulmonary function, specifically forced vital capacity (FVC) and FEV1. The study employs generalized estimating equation models to analyze how changes in MDA levels correlate with lung function metrics, indicating a potential link between oxidative stress, as represented by MDA, and respiratory health outcomes. The analysis also considers asthma severity as a modifying factor in this relationship.
